sources.title: The Red Mill (1927) | Colorized Public Domain Silent Comedy with Marion Davies & Roscoe Arbuckle
sources.description:
The Red Mill (1927) is a silent romantic comedy directed by William Goodrich (pseudonym of Roscoe Arbuckle) and produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer during the height of the silent era. This beautifully restored and colorized edition of the public domain classic brings back the charm, humor, and spectacle of 1920s Hollywood for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond. With Marion Davies in one of her most memorable comedic roles, this film captures the brilliance of early cinema and the enduring appeal of physical comedy.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Tina (Marion Davies), a humble servant girl working at the Red Mill tavern in Holland. Dreaming of romance and a better life, she becomes entangled in a mistaken identity plot involving Gretchen (Louise Fazenda), the daughter of a wealthy innkeeper. When Gretchen refuses to marry the suitor her father has chosen, Tina is mistaken for her and caught in a whirlwind of comedic confusion. Meanwhile, Tina herself falls for Captain Jacop Van Goop (Owen Moore), a handsome but penniless soldier.

Through slapstick humor, elaborate set pieces, and clever misunderstandings, The Red Mill builds toward a lively climax featuring chases, disguises, and the magic of silent-era comedy. Itâ€™s a tale of mistaken love, social barriers, and the triumph of sincerity over wealth and status.

Film Significance:
The Red Mill is notable both for its lavish MGM production values and for being directed by Roscoe Arbuckle under the pseudonym William Goodrich. Arbuckle, once one of the biggest stars in silent comedy, was working behind the scenes after his infamous career collapse. The film is also a showcase for Marion Davies, whose comedic timing and charm helped secure her place as one of the leading ladies of the silent era.

This film combines slapstick comedy with romantic farce, showcasing elaborate sets and the kind of physical humor that defined the 1920s. It remains an important cultural artifact, reflecting the transition from vaudeville-inspired silent comedy to the more structured romantic comedies of the late 1920s.

metadata.Plot: Tina works as a barmaid at the Red Mill Tavern and is at the mercy of volatile and bad tempered owner, Willem. Dennis is a visitor to the area and Tina soon falls in love with him. Dennis doesn't share her feeling and leaves only to return later on. He becomes interested in Gretchen, the Burgomaster's daughter. However, Gretchen, about to enter into an arranged marriage with the Governor, is in love with Captain Jacop Van Goop. Tina and Gretchen enter into an elaborate masquerade in order to be with the men they each love.
